name: search_value
description: Find columns across the data lake whose actual data values match the query. Use this to find which tables contain a specific data point (e.g., finding where the city 'Los Angeles' appears in the rows). Returns matching columns, their table names, and relevance scores.

query.description: The specific data value to search for within column contents.

top_k.description: Maximum number of results to return (default 10).

dedup_tables.description: If true, collapses results to unique tables, keeping only the best-scoring column per table.

name: search_field
description: Find columns or tables whose names (attributes/schema) match the query. Use this when you are looking for tables that have specific column names (e.g., searching for 'population' or 'federalShareObligated'). Returns matching tables and columns sorted by relevance.

query.description: The attribute (column) name or table name to search for.

top_k.description: Maximum number of results to return (default 10).

dedup_tables.description: If true, collapses results to unique tables, keeping only the best-scoring column per table.

name: neighbor
description: Find cross-table relationships (neighbors) for a given table or column. Use this when you need to join tables or find related datasets. 'pkfk' finds primary/foreign key links (best for joining), 'content' finds columns with overlapping data values, and 'schema' finds columns with similar names. Always excludes results from the same input table.

input.description: The starting table name (e.g., 'dataset_id/file.csv') or exact column network ID (e.g., 'dataset_id/file.csv.col_name').

relation.description: The type of relationship to traverse. Use 'pkfk' for strict joins, 'content' for value overlaps, or 'schema' for name similarity.

top_k.description: Maximum number of results to return. Leave empty for all.
